content: our world is broken stagnant fallen into the abyss once human is surprising it's a free-to-play open world survival crafting game which is a word salad of flavor of the month genres if ever there was one and it takes those well-worn ideas and simplifies them into relatively basic forms and yet I'm not ready to put it down even after dozens of hours it's so fun and so weird that I can't help but think about my next Supply run alien monster fight or home construction project there's no shortage of post-apocalyptic survival games out there but once human take on that setup feels unique and interesting rather than your classic zombie or nuclear war scenario it wraps the end of the world around an alien an infestation it's a fun approach that seems underused in the genre and once human puts it to use in some really clever ways now do you see it a glimmer within the void this alien organism has the ability to turn basically anything into a grotesque monster living or otherwise sure that shuffling and Starling person may seem like a zombie but then it turns around and reveals it has a blinding stage light for AE I fought light bulbs that have turned into giant spiders evil trees and whatever this is that keeps once Human full of surprises not all of the strange creatures are hostile deviations are creatures you can capture and then use either in battle or to help you out around your base they are essentially the Pokémon of the alien apocalypse you can carry one into combat in your backpack like my festering gel here which can reshape itself into makeshift cover when thrown others like the Digby boy are best put to use at home helping with chores to like collecting ore they're endearing useful and utterly bizarre perfectly suited for this world your Weaponry on the other hand is fairly basic the Arsenal consists of simple melee weapons like blades and bats as well as your general pistols rifles shotguns small arm options you can repair or upgrade things you craft but not the often better gear you'll find out in the field you can however use them until they wear out then dismantle them for the blueprints which cleverly encourages you to try things out before investing the time and resources needed to craft your own the weapons may be conventional but the enemies you defeat with them most definitely are not you'll come up against everything from a monster with a traffic cone for a head to to this guy that would look at home in God of War sure most of the fights are resolv by simply flailing your melee weapon or running around in circles and shooting as you drain health bars but the bosses do a nice job of mixing in Unique Mechanics like forcing you to kill monster spawners to make them vulnerable the creatures are the best looking things in once human with organic and inorganic meeting in a strange body horror aesthetic I just wish the of the world lean into it more you can see some Decay but not to the degree that stands out in something like The Last of Us series which seems like a missed opportunity the biggest monsters are reserved for instanced dungeons similar to Classic World of Warcraft design these fights are geared towards groups of up to four players and once human makes forming pickup parties easy a click of a button brings up a server wide team finder where you can browse what sort of groups other people are looking for or start your own it's very easy easy to put together a group like this and the fact that no words or other back and forth is necessary makes it painless even for online introverts like myself I just wish it were possible to bring your character along when you switch servers right now if you aren't on the same server as a friend someone will need to start from scratch in order for you to play together which is an unfortunate misstep outside of combat there is a a simple linear main quest in a smattering of optional side missions not a whole lot is done with the main quest as it seems to mostly serve as an excuse to push you towards new areas rather than an actual Story the missions themselves are largely the same Loop of visiting an area activating a bunch of Rift anchors and then fighting the Region's boss which did get pretty tiresome by the end nice and easy well done I do however appreciate the times once human leans into the strange of his world like when I was sent to hunt a monster that kept turning pregnant people into trees seriously plenty of green leaves she's just not a person anymore the map is huge with regions roughly separated by enemy level and topography it's big but far from empty every neighborhood or research lab is dense with monstrosities to fight and loot and every open space is a potential Homestead to build on can take a long time to cross from one part of the world to the other by foot which is why I'm glad an early quest gave me a motorcycle that I can summon any time and is fun to zoom around on there are also Transportation Towers to unlock which act as fast travel points and even a glider which all help make the distance much more manageable the level curve is in need of some work however it's easy to keep up in the early and mid game but by the by the time you reach the final areas enemies are at such a high level that you are stuck with the choice of being easily one shot or grinding for hours to work your way to parody there's nothing wrong with getting your butt kicked and then working to beep up your character to return the favor down the line but just how suddenly that challenge spikes up makes the climb more daunting than aspirational the survival crafting aspects benefit from being very simple and straightforward you have very few things you can craft at the start but as you accumulate XP and level up you get mimetic ciphers which let you unlock nodes on four upgrade trees it's a less is more approach that makes it easy to get back to the action which I appreciate Gathering materials is still done via the tried and true runaround and punch trees method and at least early on supplies are abundant enough that heading out for some mining doesn't feel laborious resources seem to grow back quickly and as you level up you get access to things like automated mining or rainfall catchers that move you from a hunter gatherer into your own Industrial Revolution which is very rewarding building a home is generally pretty easy thanks to the well-laid out menu I'm no Craftsman but even I was able to build this lovely split level house on a riverbed easily enough the trickiest part is getting the individual pieces to face the direction you want and some of my hardest fights have just been trying to get the sections of my roof lined up correctly it's great that you can see other players houses for inspiration and I appreciate that you can save a blueprint of your own which lets you pack up and move to a new area then recreate it almost instantaneously as once human is a live service game there is a road map for more content ahead this includes things like the next steps in the story technical additions like controller support and special events most importantly each season which lasts 6 weeks ends with a wipe of the servers similar to what happens in Escape From tarov that sounds scary but the blueprints you collect remain including the one for your house as does Quest progress there's no way to know just yet if that's a fun Clean Slate or a terrible nuisance but thinking about how I'll approach that has me intrigued and fairly optimistic as you reach the latter half of the story you also unlock Eternal land which is essentially an alternate buildon mode on a private server it has a pair of unique currencies called astral sand an astralite that can be used to buy everything from seeds to fishing rods to Scenic elements like stones and trees importantly Eternal land is free of the seasonal wipes which is an appealing option if you want to build your dream home and show it off to friends without worry once human is a lot of fun with survival crafting that is simple and accessible but still rewarding to dig into building a house is amusing even if pieces aren't always Cooperative about snapping together in the right direction and while the combat is generally pretty basic the grotesque weirdness of the monsters more than makes up for that especially when you get a managerie of weird little creatures of your own to fight with Once human would benefit from more creative quests in a flatter difficulty curve but I still had a great time and I'm eager to continue my adventures in this Twisted world as its first season progresses for more strange new worlds be sure to check out our reviews of Nightingale or the first descendant and for everything else stick with IGN
title: Once Human Review
author: IGN

key_facts: FACT: Once Human is a free-to-play open-world survival crafting game with a post-apocalyptic alien infestation theme.
FACT: The game features grotesque monsters created by an alien organism that transforms living and inorganic matter.
FACT: Players can capture non-hostile creatures called Deviations to use in combat or for base chores.
FACT: Weaponry consists of basic melee tools and firearms, which can be repaired, upgraded, or dismantled for blueprints.
FACT: The game includes instanced dungeon-style boss fights designed for groups of up to four players.
FACT: A server-wide team finder allows instant group formation without communication, ideal for online introverts.
FACT: Players cannot transfer their character between servers, requiring friends to start fresh if on different ones.
FACT: The main quest is linear and primarily serves to guide players to new areas rather than deliver deep narrative.
FACT: Side missions follow a repetitive loop: activate Rift anchors and defeat regional bosses.
FACT: The map is large and divided by enemy level and terrain, with dense loot and monster spawns across regions.
FACT: Players can unlock transportation options like motorcycles, Transportation Towers, and gliders for faster travel.
FACT: Crafting is simplified through XP progression and mimetic ciphers that unlock upgrade trees.
FACT: Resources regenerate quickly, and automation tools like rainfall catchers help transition from gathering to industrial production.
FACT: Home building uses an intuitive menu system, though aligning structures precisely can be challenging.
FACT: Players can save and reuse house blueprints to rebuild in new locations instantly.
key_opinions: OPINION: The alien infestation concept offers a refreshing twist compared to overused zombie or nuclear war tropes.
OPINION: The grotesque creature designs are the most visually compelling aspect of the game’s aesthetic.
OPINION: The game’s world could have leaned more into decay and environmental storytelling, similar to The Last of Us.
OPINION: The difficulty spike in late-game areas feels abrupt and discouraging rather than aspirational.
OPINION: The repetitive side mission structure becomes tiresome despite occasional creative moments.
OPINION: The lack of cross-server character transfer is a significant usability flaw for social play.
OPINION: The team finder system is excellent for casual multiplayer but lacks voice or text chat integration.
OPINION: The survival crafting system strikes a good balance between simplicity and rewarding progression.
OPINION: The ability to build and preserve homes in Eternal Land is a strong incentive for long-term engagement.
OPINION: The seasonal wipes are potentially disruptive but may encourage fresh starts and community renewal.
key_datapoints: DATA: Seasonal server wipes occur every 6 weeks, similar to Escape From Tarkov.
DATA: Blueprints and quest progress persist after server wipes, including house designs.
DATA: Players gain access to automated mining and rainfall catchers as they level up.
DATA: Upgrades are unlocked via mimetic ciphers on four distinct upgrade trees.
DATA: Transportation Towers and gliders serve as fast travel options across the vast map.
DATA: The game supports group dungeons with up to four players per instance.
DATA: Players can summon a motorcycle at any time after completing an early quest.
DATA: Eternal Land mode is free and free from seasonal wipes, offering private server gameplay.
DATA: Two unique currencies—astral sand and astralite—are used in Eternal Land for purchases.
DATA: Deviations can be carried in backpacks and used in combat or for base automation tasks.
